docs.lead_paragraph: A symposium for National Football League coaches in Miami came and went yesterday, and by many accounts it was a success. But that wasn't the big story coming out of the owners' meetings, nor was it the novelist Tom Clancy, who withdrew his bid to purchase the Vikings. The real action was several dozen feet away, where most members of the two-year-old N.F.L. Coaches Association quietly took part in a protest, a move that was immediately blasted by Commissioner Paul Tagliabue as silly.

headline.main: N.F.L. Coaches Stage Protest, but Tagliabue Calls It Silly

docs.abstract: Group of about 50 to 60 coaches, upset with issues they say include race and age discrimination, enters symposium for NFL coaches in Miami 15 minutes late; say reason for protest is to show league that coaches, particularly assistants, are unified and prepared to take on NFL; Comr Paul Tagliabue calls protest 'silly'; novelist Tom Clancy withdraws his bid to purchase Minnesota Vikings (M)
docs.snippet: A symposium for National Football League coaches in Miami came and went yesterday, and by many accounts it was a success. But that wasn't the big story coming out of the owners' meetings, nor was it the novelist Tom Clancy, who withdrew his bid to...

docs.lead_paragraph: Splintered into countless factions, the Senate began debate tonight on legislation meant to discourage youth smoking by raising cigarette prices. Even the most ardent opponents conceded that some bill would probably pass, maybe by the end of this week, but no one had a clear indication of what that measure would entail.

headline.main: Divided Senate Begins Debate on Tobacco Legislation

docs.abstract: Senate, splintered into many factions, opens debate on bill meant to discourage youth smoking by raising cigarette prices; opponents concede some version is likely to pass; Sen John McCain, chief sponsor of main bill, comments; bill would raise cigarette prices by $1.10 a pack over five years, give Food and Drug Administration greater authority to regulate tobacco production and marketing, set steep penalties on tobacco companies if youth smoking fails to drop and place annual ceiling on damage payments by cigarette makers; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Splintered into countless factions, the Senate began debate tonight on legislation meant to discourage youth smoking by raising cigarette prices.    Even the most ardent opponents conceded that some bill would probably pass, maybe by the end of this...

docs.lead_paragraph: Geraldine A. Ferraro sought yesterday to undercut Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato's effort to present himself as a champion of victims of breast cancer, asserting that he was a captive of the insurance industry who was pushing breast cancer legislation that served ''the interests of insurance companies.'' The attack by Ms. Ferraro, a Democratic candidate for Senate, came one day after Mr. D'Amato formally announced his bid for a fourth term with a woman who suffered from breast cancer at his side. The swiftness of Ms. Ferraro's response suggested the extent to which women's issues would dominate the Senate race -- particularly if Ms. Ferraro wins a Democratic primary in September against Representative Charles E. Schumer of Brooklyn and Mark Green, the New York City Public Advocate.

headline.main: Ferraro Assails D'Amato Over Breast Cancer Effort

docs.abstract: Democratic senatorial candidate Geraldine A Ferraro seeks to undercut Sen Alfonse M D'Amato's effort to present himself as champion of victims of breast cancer; asserts that he is pushing breast cancer legislation that serves 'interests of insurance companies'; Ferraro, in assailing D'Amato's breast cancer legislation, puts herself at odds with Sen Dianne Feinstein, Democrat who is co-sponsor of legislation (M)
docs.snippet: Geraldine A. Ferraro sought yesterday to undercut Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato's effort to present himself as a champion of victims of breast cancer, asserting that he was a captive of the insurance industry who was pushing breast cancer legislation...

docs.lead_paragraph: U.S. Attacks Microsoft In 2 Broad Antitrust Suits The Federal Government and 20 state Attorneys General filed two broad, aggressive antitrust suits against Microsoft, in the Government's most concerted attack on a company in a generation. The suits, announced by Attorney General Janet Reno, accuse the company, the world's largest software producer, of leveraging its monopoly in personal-computer operating systems to win control of other software, notably the browsers used for access to the World Wide Web. [Page A1.]

docs.lead_paragraph: Newly unearthed documents suggest that German insurance companies went beyond what was previously known in conniving with the Nazis to avoid paying Jewish policyholders after the rampage through German cities in 1938 known as Kristallnacht. The documents indicate that the companies also sometimes exceeded Government guidelines and canceled unrelated life, health and pension policies on which Jews had been paying premiums for years. Article, page A9.

headline.main: Light Cast on Ties Of Insurers to Nazis

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-9 Scientists Say India Tested a Hydrogen Bomb In a disclosure that could accelerate a nuclear arms race with Pakistan, Indian scientists confirmed that the largest of the five underground nuclear tests they conducted last week involved a hydrogen bomb, a device with potentially enormous power that is known in military circles as a ''city-buster.'' A1 Foreign Minister Gohar Ayub Khan of Pakistan said his country has decided to begin testing nuclear weapons in response to India's tests last week, but it was not clear whether he was speaking on behalf of his Government. A8

docs.lead_paragraph: A new Federal study finds that 4.7 million children far more than previously estimated -- are eligible for Medicaid but are not enrolled in the program and have no health insurance benefits. The finding means that two of every five uninsured children in the United States could have coverage through Medicaid, which provides comprehensive health benefits, if they or their parents would just apply for it.

headline.main: More Children Go Uninsured Despite Status For Medicaid

docs.abstract: Study by Federal Agency for Health Care Policy Research finds 4.7 million children, or far more than previously estimated, are eligible for Medicaid but are not enrolled in program and have no insurance benefits (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In an outburst of anti-Semitic violence that presaged the Holocaust, mobs incited by the Nazis rampaged through Berlin and other German cities on Nov. 9 and 10, 1938, smashing and torching an estimated 171 synagogues and thousands of Jewish shops and homes. Nearly 60 years later, fresh details surrounding Kristallnacht, or ''night of broken glass,'' have been extracted from Government archives in Moscow that have been storing Nazi documents seized by Soviet troops in 1945.

headline.main: Insurers Swindled Jews, Nazi Files Show

docs.abstract: Fresh details surrounding Kristallnacht, outburst of anti-Semitic violence in Germany that presaged Holocaust, have been extracted from Government archives in Moscow that have been storing Nazi documents seized by Soviet troops in 1945; newly unearthed documents suggest German insurance companies not only connived with Nazis to avoid paying Jewish policyholders for damages to synagogues and thousands of Jewish shops and homes, but sometimes also exceeded Government guidelines and canceled all policies on which Jews had been paying premiums for years (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL 3-15 Indonesian Leader Sees Different Reality President Suharto of Indonesia faces some agonizing choices in responding to the snowballing movement against him. Yet one reason for the turmoil is that the perceptions that frame his decision-making are a world apart from those that invigorate his opponents. 1
